member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.AllowNullAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that null is allowed as an input even if the corresponding type disallows it.

member.summary: Indicates that the specified method parameter expects a constant.
member.remarks: This can be used to inform tooling that a constant should be used as an argument for the annotated parameter.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ConstantExpectedAttribute.Min
member.summary: Indicates the minimum bound of the expected constant, inclusive.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ConstantExpectedAttribute.Max
member.summary: Indicates the maximum bound of the expected constant, inclusive.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DisallowNullAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that null is disallowed as an input even if the corresponding type allows it.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DoesNotReturnAttribute
member.summary: Applied to a method that will never return under any circumstance.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DoesNotReturnIfAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that the method will not return if the associated Boolean parameter is passed the specified value.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DoesNotReturnIfAttribute.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes the attribute with the specified parameter value.
member.param: The condition parameter value. Code after the method will be considered unreachable by diagnostics if the argument to the associated parameter matches this value.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DoesNotReturnIfAttribute.ParameterValue

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that an API is experimental and it may change in the future.
member.remarks: This attribute allows call sites to be flagged with a diagnostic that indicates that an experimental feature is used. Authors can use this attribute to ship preview features in their assemblies.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, specifying the ID that the compiler will use when reporting a use of the API the attribute applies to.
member.param: The ID that the compiler will use when reporting a use of the API the attribute applies to.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.DiagnosticId
member.summary: Gets the ID that the compiler will use when reporting a use of the API the attribute applies to.
member.remarks:
The diagnostic ID is shown in build output for warnings and errors.
This property represents the unique ID that can be used to suppress the warnings or errors, if needed.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.UrlFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL for corresponding documentation. The API accepts a format string instead of an actual URL, creating a generic URL that includes the diagnostic ID.
member.value: The format string that represents a URL to corresponding documentation.
member.remarks: An example format string is https://contoso.com/obsoletion-warnings/{0}.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnscopedRefAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate a byref escapes and is not scoped.

remarks.para: There are several cases where the C# compiler treats a as implicitly - where the compiler does not allow the to escape the method.

For example:
for instance methods.
parameters that refer to types.
parameters.
This attribute is used in those instances where the should be allowed to escape.

Applying this attribute, in any form, has impact on consumers of the applicable API. It is necessary for API authors to understand the lifetime implications of applying this attribute and how it may impact their users.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMembersAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that certain members on a specified are accessed dynamically, for example through .
member.remarks:
This allows tools to understand which members are being accessed during the execution of a program.
This attribute is valid on members whose type is or .
When this attribute is applied to a location of type , the assumption is that the string represents a fully qualified type name.
When this attribute is applied to a class, interface, or struct, the members specified can be accessed dynamically on instances returned from calling on instances of that class, interface, or struct.
If the attribute is applied to a method it's treated as a special case and it implies the attribute should be applied to the "this" parameter of the method. As such the attribute should only be used on instance methods of types assignable to System.Type (or string, but no methods will use it there).

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMembersAttribute.#ctor(System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified member types.
member.param: The types of members dynamically accessed.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMembersAttribute.MemberTypes
member.summary: Gets the which specifies the type of members dynamically accessed.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes
member.summary:
Specifies the types of members that are dynamically accessed.
This enumeration has a attribute that allows a bitwise combination of its member values.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes.None
member.summary: Specifies no members.

member.summary: Specifies the default, parameterless public constructor.

member.summary: Specifies all public constructors.

member.summary: Specifies all non-public constructors.

member.summary: Specifies all public methods.

member.summary: Specifies all non-public methods.

member.summary: Specifies all public fields.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes.NonPublicFields
member.summary: Specifies all non-public fields.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes.PublicNestedTypes
member.summary: Specifies all public nested types.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes.NonPublicNestedTypes
member.summary: Specifies all non-public nested types.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes.PublicProperties
member.summary: Specifies all public properties.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes.NonPublicProperties
member.summary: Specifies all non-public properties.

member.summary: Specifies all public events.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes.NonPublicEvents
member.summary: Specifies all non-public events.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes.Interfaces
member.summary: Specifies all interfaces implemented by the type.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMemberTypes.All
member.summary: Specifies all members.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicDependencyAttribute
member.summary: States a dependency that one member has on another.
member.remarks: This can be used to inform tooling of a dependency that is otherwise not evident purely from metadata and IL, for example a member relied on via reflection.

member.remarks: Either must be a valid string or must not equal , but not both.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.FeatureGuardAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the specified public static boolean get-only property guards access to the specified feature.
member.remarks: Analyzers can use this to prevent warnings on calls to code that is annotated as requiring that feature, when the callsite is guarded by a call to the property.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.FeatureGuardAttribute.FeatureType
member.summary: The type that represents the feature guarded by the property.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.FeatureSwitchDefinitionAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the specified public static boolean get-only property corresponds to the feature switch specified by name.
member.remarks: IL rewriters and compilers can use this to substitute the return value of the specified property with the value of the feature switch.

member.remarks: This allows tools to understand which methods are unsafe to call when compiling ahead of time.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute
member.summary: Suppresses reporting of a specific rule violation, allowing multiple suppressions on a single code artifact.
member.remarks: is different than in that it doesn't have a . So it is always preserved in the compiled assembly.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, specifying the category of the tool and the identifier for an analysis rule.
member.param: The category for the attribute.
The identifier of the analysis rule the attribute applies to.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Category
member.summary: Gets the category identifying the classification of the attribute.
member.remarks: The property describes the tool or tool analysis category for which a message suppression attribute applies.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.CheckId
member.summary: Gets the identifier of the analysis tool rule to be suppressed.
member.remarks: Concatenated together, the and properties form a unique check identifier.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Scope
member.summary: Gets or sets the scope of the code that is relevant for the attribute.
member.remarks: The Scope property is an optional argument that specifies the metadata scope for which the attribute is relevant.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Target
member.summary: Gets or sets a fully qualified path that represents the target of the attribute.
member.remarks: The property is an optional argument identifying the analysis target of the attribute. An example value is "System.IO.Stream.ctor():System.Void". Because it is fully qualified, it can be long, particularly for targets such as parameters. The analysis tool user interface should be capable of automatically formatting the parameter.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.MessageId
member.summary: Gets or sets an optional argument expanding on exclusion criteria.
member.remarks: The property is an optional argument that specifies additional exclusion where the literal metadata target is not sufficiently precise. For example, the cannot be applied within a method, and it may be desirable to suppress a violation against a statement in the method that will give a rule violation, but not against all statements in the method.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Justification
member.summary: Gets or sets the justification for suppressing the code analysis message.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.DebuggerDisableUserUnhandledExceptionsAttribute
member.summary: If a .NET Debugger is attached which supports the Debugger.BreakForUserUnhandledException(Exception) API, this attribute will prevent the debugger from breaking on user-unhandled exceptions when the exception is caught by a method with this attribute, unless BreakForUserUnhandledException is called.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.StackTraceHiddenAttribute

member.name: T:System.Index
member.summary: Represent a type can be used to index a collection either from the start or the end.

member.name: M:System.Index.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Construct an Index using a value and indicating if the index is from the start or from the end.
member.param: The index value. it has to be zero or positive number.
Indicating if the index is from the start or from the end.
member.remarks: If the Index constructed from the end, index value 1 means pointing at the last element and index value 0 means pointing at beyond last element.

member.name: P:System.Index.Start
member.summary: Create an Index pointing at first element.

member.name: P:System.Index.End
member.summary: Create an Index pointing at beyond last element.

member.name: M:System.Index.FromStart(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create an Index from the start at the position indicated by the value.
member.param: The index value from the start.

member.name: M:System.Index.FromEnd(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create an Index from the end at the position indicated by the value.
member.param: The index value from the end.

member.name: P:System.Index.Value
member.summary: Returns the index value.

member.name: P:System.Index.IsFromEnd
member.summary: Indicates whether the index is from the start or the end.

member.name: M:System.Index.GetOffset(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate the offset from the start using the giving collection length.
member.param: The length of the collection that the Index will be used with. length has to be a positive value
member.remarks: For performance reason, we don't validate the input length parameter and the returned offset value against negative values. we don't validate either the returned offset is greater than the input length. It is expected Index will be used with collections which always have non negative length/count. If the returned offset is negative and then used to index a collection will get out of range exception which will be same affect as the validation.

member.summary: Converts integer number to an Index.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsExternalInit
member.summary: Reserved to be used by the compiler for tracking metadata. This class should not be used by developers in source code.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ModuleInitializerAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that a method should be called in its containing module's initializer.
member.remarks:
When one or more valid methods with this attribute are found in a compilation, the compiler will emit a module initializer which calls each of the attributed methods.
Certain requirements are imposed on any method targeted with this attribute: - The method must be `static`. - The method must be an ordinary member method, as opposed to a property accessor, constructor, local function, etc. - The method must be parameterless. - The method must return `void`. - The method must not be generic or be contained in a generic type. - The method's effective accessibility must be `internal` or `public`.
The specification for module initializers in the .NET runtime can be found here: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/specs/Ecma-335-Augments.md#module-initializer

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.OverloadResolutionPriorityAttribute
member.summary: Specifies the priority of a member in overload resolution. When unspecified, the default priority is 0.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.OverloadResolutionPriorityAttribute.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The priority of the attributed member. Higher numbers are prioritized, lower numbers are deprioritized. 0 is the default if no attribute is present.

member.name: P:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.OverloadResolutionPriorityAttribute.Priority
member.summary: The priority of the member.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ParamCollectionAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a method will allow a variable number of arguments in its invocation.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.RequiredMemberAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that a type has required members or that a member is required.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.RequiresLocationAttribute
member.summary: Reserved for use by a compiler for tracking metadata. This attribute should not be used by developers in source code.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.SkipLocalsInitAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that the .locals init flag should not be set in method headers.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.DisableRuntimeMarshallingAttribute
member.summary: Disables the built-in runtime managed/unmanaged marshalling subsystem for P/Invokes, Delegate types, and unmanaged function pointer invocations.
member.remarks:
The built-in marshalling subsystem has some behaviors that cannot be changed due to backward-compatibility requirements. This attribute allows disabling the built-in subsystem and instead uses the following rules for P/Invokes, Delegates, and unmanaged function pointer invocations:
- All value types that do not contain reference type fields recursively (unmanaged in C#) are blittable - Value types that recursively have any fields that have [StructLayout(LayoutKind.Auto)] are disallowed from interop. - All reference types are disallowed from usage in interop scenarios. - SetLastError support in P/Invokes is disabled. - varargs support is disabled. - LCIDConversionAttribute support is disabled.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.UnsafeAccessorAttribute
member.summary: Provides access to an inaccessible member of a specific type.

member.param: The kind of the target to which access is provided.

member.name: P:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.UnsafeAccessorAttribute.Kind
member.summary: Gets the kind of member to which access is provided.

member.name: P:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.UnsafeAccessorAttribute.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the member to which access is provided.
member.remarks: The name defaults to the annotated method name if not specified. The name must be unset/null for .

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.UnsafeAccessorKind
member.summary: Specifies the kind of target to which an is providing access.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.UnsafeAccessorKind.Constructor
member.summary: Provide access to a constructor.

member.summary: Provide access to a static field.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Returns the optional message associated with this attribute instance.

member.summary: Returns the optional URL associated with this attribute instance.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.ObsoletedOSPlatformAttribute
member.summary: Marks APIs that were obsoleted in a given operating system version.
member.remarks: Primarily used by OS bindings to indicate APIs that should not be used anymore.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.SupportedOSPlatformAttribute
member.summary: Records the operating system (and minimum version) that supports an API. Multiple attributes can be applied to indicate support on multiple operating systems.
member.remarks:
Callers can apply a or use guards to prevent calls to APIs on unsupported operating systems.
A given platform should only be specified once.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.SupportedOSPlatformGuardAttribute
member.summary: Annotates a custom guard field, property or method with a supported platform name and optional version. Multiple attributes can be applied to indicate guard for multiple supported platforms.
member.remarks:
Callers can apply a to a field, property or method and use that field, property or method in a conditional or assert statements in order to safely call platform specific APIs.
The type of the field or property should be boolean, the method return type should be boolean in order to be used as platform guard.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.TargetPlatformAttribute
member.summary: Records the platform that the project targeted.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.UnsupportedOSPlatformAttribute
member.summary: Marks APIs that were removed in a given operating system version.
member.remarks: Primarily used by OS bindings to indicate APIs that are only available in earlier versions.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.UnsupportedOSPlatformGuardAttribute
member.summary: Annotates the custom guard field, property or method with an unsupported platform name and optional version. Multiple attributes can be applied to indicate guard for multiple unsupported platforms.
member.remarks:
Callers can apply a to a field, property or method and use that field, property or method in a conditional or assert statements as a guard to safely call APIs unsupported on those platforms.
The type of the field or property should be boolean, the method return type should be boolean in order to be used as platform guard.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices2.InlineArrayAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the instance's storage is sequentially replicated "length" times.

remarks.para: This attribute can be used to annotate a type with a single field. The runtime will replicate that field in the actual type layout as many times as is specified.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices2.InlineArrayAttribute.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new instance with the specified length.
member.param: The number of sequential fields to replicate in the inline array type.

member.name: P:System.Runtime.CompilerServices2.InlineArrayAttribute.Length
member.summary: Gets the number of sequential fields to replicate in the inline array type.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.InteropServices.SuppressGCTransitionAttribute
member.summary: An attribute used to indicate a GC transition should be skipped when making an unmanaged function call.
member.remarks:
This attribute is ignored if applied to a method without the .
Forgoing this transition can yield benefits when the cost of the transition is more than the execution time of the unmanaged function. However, avoiding this transition removes some of the guarantees the runtime provides through a normal P/Invoke. When exiting the managed runtime to enter an unmanaged function the GC must transition from Cooperative mode into Preemptive mode. Full details on these modes can be found at https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/coding-guidelines/clr-code-guide.md#2.1.8. Suppressing the GC transition is an advanced scenario and should not be done without fully understanding potential consequences.
One of these consequences is an impact to Mixed-mode debugging (https://docs.microsoft.com/visualstudio/debugger/how-to-debug-in-mixed-mode). During Mixed-mode debugging, it is not possible to step into or set breakpoints in a P/Invoke that has been marked with this attribute. A workaround is to switch to native debugging and set a breakpoint in the native function. In general, usage of this attribute is not recommended if debugging the P/Invoke is important, for example stepping through the native code or diagnosing an exception thrown from the native code.
The runtime may load the native library for method marked with this attribute in advance before the method is called for the first time. Usage of this attribute is not recommended for platform neutral libraries with conditional platform specific code.
The P/Invoke method that this attribute is applied to must have all of the following properties: * Native function always executes for a trivial amount of time (less than 1 microsecond). * Native function does not perform a blocking syscall (e.g. any type of I/O). * Native function does not call back into the runtime (e.g. Reverse P/Invoke). * Native function does not throw exceptions. * Native function does not manipulate locks or other concurrency primitives.
Consequences of invalid uses of this attribute: * GC starvation. * Immediate runtime termination. * Data corruption.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.InteropServices.UnmanagedCallersOnlyAttribute
member.summary: Any method marked with can be directly called from native code. The function token can be loaded to a local variable using the address-of operator in C# and passed as a callback to a native method.
member.remarks: Methods marked with this attribute have the following restrictions: * Method must be marked "static". * Must not be called from managed code. * Must only have blittable arguments.

member.name: F:System.Runtime.InteropServices.UnmanagedCallersOnlyAttribute.CallConvs
member.summary: Optional. If omitted, the runtime will use the default platform calling convention.
member.remarks: Supplied types must be from the official "System.Runtime.CompilerServices" namespace and be of the form "CallConvXXX".

member.name: F:System.Runtime.InteropServices.UnmanagedCallersOnlyAttribute.EntryPoint
member.summary: Optional. If omitted, no named export is emitted during compilation.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.InteropServices.WasmImportLinkageAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that the P/Invoke marked with this attribute should be linked in as a WASM import.
member.remarks: See https://webassembly.github.io/spec/core/syntax/modules.html#imports.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.InteropServices.WasmImportLinkageAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Instance constructor.
